Six months later, Bayrou is still France's PM – and not finished
subhead: With no majority to back him in the Assemblée Nationale, Prime Minister François Bayrou has governed from a precarious position. He has held on, so far, thanks to a fragile agreement with the Socialists to re-examine the unpopular 2023 reform of the pensions system.

title: Trump demands 'unconditional surrender' from Iran in series of posts

China, Iran's main economic backer, remains a bystander to the Middle East conflict
subhead: As Chinese diplomacy becomes increasingly active in the Middle East, Beijing – which buys 90% of Iran's exported oil – has continued to leave the role of regional policing to the US.

title: G7 rallies behind Ukraine after Trump's sudden exit
subhead: Hosting the summit, Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney welcomed Volodymr Zelensky on Tuesday and announced Can$2 billion of military support, including drones and helicopters, for Ukraine.

title: Is it ever a good idea to… wear your clothes backwards?
subhead: In fashion, as in life, it is important to know the lines you should not cross − or else, to do so deliberately.

title: The US refusal to intervene in Syria in 2013: A French trauma
subhead: 'The Transatlantic Divorce' (3/5). On August 31, 2013, as French warplanes were en route to Syria to launch a joint operation with the US against the regime of Bashar al-Assad, which had used chemical weapons against its own people, Barack Obama decided to delay, leaving France alone and powerless.

title: The failure of Obama's 'leading from behind' in Libya
subhead: 'The Transatlantic Divorce' (2/5). Elected on the promise of no longer sending American troops to the Middle East, President Barack Obama allowed France and the UK to lead the Libyan operation, which resulted in Muammar Gaddafi's fall. He emerged deeply frustrated by the shortcomings of his European allies.

title: UK government reverses course and launches national inquiry into 'grooming gangs'
subhead: After a damning audit by a senior civil servant, Prime Minister Keir Starmer confirmed that the networks of sexual predators who operated for decades in the United Kingdom would be subject to a public inquiry.
